title: 113_s875
content: The Act titled "Department of Veterans Affairs Disease Reporting and Oversight Act of 2013" requires the Veterans Health Administration to report cases of infectious diseases at its facilities. The Department of Veterans Affairs Disease Reporting and Oversight Act of 2013 mandates reporting of infectious diseases at Veterans Health Administration facilities within 24 hours to specified authorities. The Department of Veterans Affairs Disease Reporting and Oversight Act of 2013 requires reporting of infectious diseases at Veterans Health Administration facilities within 24 hours to specified authorities, including the county agency or department responsible for handling such diseases. This includes notifying individuals who have contracted or are at risk of contracting the disease, their next of kin, primary health care provider, and employees of the Department. The Department of Veterans Affairs Disease Reporting and Oversight Act of 2013 mandates reporting of notifiable infectious diseases at Veterans Health Administration facilities within 24 hours. If a state requires quicker reporting or suspected cases to be reported before confirmation, the director must comply. A notifiable infectious disease is defined as any infectious disease on the nationally notifiable diseases list. The Department of Veterans Affairs Disease Reporting and Oversight Act of 2013 mandates reporting of notifiable infectious diseases at Veterans Health Administration facilities within 24 hours. If a state requires quicker reporting or suspected cases to be reported before confirmation, the director must comply. Within seven days of confirming a notifiable infectious disease, the director must develop an action plan to prevent its spread, involving federal, state, and local entities. Recordkeeping requirements are also specified for each Veterans Integrated Service Network director. The director of each Veterans Integrated Service Network must keep records of notices submitted for at least 10 years. The Inspector General must report to Congress annually on compliance with the requirements. If non-compliance is suspected, an investigation will be conducted. The Secretary can suspend a director for non-compliance with the section's provisions and impose additional disciplinary actions. The Under Secretary for Health must issue a directive to specific teams within the Veterans Health Administration within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Under Secretary for Health must consult with the Veterans Health Administration and other relevant groups on actions to be taken when a notifiable infectious disease is found in a VA facility. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. "7330B. Reporting of infectious diseases."
